questions.text: The following organism shows positive hair perforation test:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T. Mentagrophytes Positive hair perforation is seen in some dermatophytes, especially T mentagrophytes. It is also used to differentiate common isolates i.e. T mentagrophytes from T rubrum. It is positive for T mentagrophytes, M. canis. The test is performed by inoculating the colony into a petri dish with water, yeast extract and hair. Fungi pierce the hair and produce wedge shaped perforations.

Table:

#MANTRA Hair Perforation Test for Dermatophytes

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and hepatomegaly. What is the vector for the parasite having kinetoplast in one of its morphological forms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Sandfly Given case scenario points to the possible diagnosis of leishmaniasis. Leishmaniasis is caused by protozoan parasites which are transmitted by the bite of infected female phlebotomine sandflies. Leishmania exists in non-flagellated amastigote form (with nucleus and kinetoplast) and flagellated promastigote form.

Highyeild:

There are 3 main forms of leishmaniases – visceral (also known as kala-azar, which is and the most serious form of the disease), cutaneous (the most common), and mucocutaneous. Visceral leishmaniasis (VL), also known as kala-azar is fatal if left untreated in over 95% of cases. It is characterized by irregular bouts of fever, weight loss, enlargement of the spleen and liver, and anaemia. Most cases occur in Brazil, East Africa and in India. It remains one of the top parasitic diseases with outbreak and mortality potential. Cutaneous leishmaniasis (CL) is the most common form of leishmaniasis and causes skin lesions, mainly ulcers, on exposed parts of the body, leaving life-long scars and serious disability or stigma. Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis leads to partial or total destruction of mucous membranes of the nose, mouth and throat. The life cycle of Leishmania species: Sandflies inject infective promastigotes into a susceptible mammal during feeding. Promastigotes are phagocytosed by resident phagocytes, transform into tissue-stage amastigotes, and multiply within these cells through simple The parasite continues to infect phagocytic cells either at the site of cutaneous infection or in secondary lymphoid organs, with eventual parasitemia. Sandflies become infected through feeding on a host either with an active skin lesion in CL or with parasitemia in VL. Parasites convert to promastigotes within the sandfly midgut. Promastigotes migrate from the midgut and transform into highly infectious metacyclic promastigotes.

questions.text: A young patient presented with urethral discharge with a history of sexual contact with commercial sex workers after 3 days. The most likely causative organism for the patient's condition is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Neisseria gonorrhoea The most likely causative organism with the given scenario is Neisseria gonorrhoeae which is a common cause of urethritis and associated with purulent genital discharge. Comparison of Gonococcal and nongonococcal urethritis

Table:

#MANTRA Features Gonococcal urethritis Non-gonococcal urethritis Onset 48 hours Longer (>1 week) Urethral discharge Purulent (flow of seed-resembling semen) Mucous to mucopurulent Complication DGI (polyarthritis and endocarditis) Water-can perineum Reiter's syndrome: Characterized by conjunctivitis, urethritis, arthritis and mucosal lesions Diagnosis ⮚ Gram stain ⮚ Culture on Thayer Martin media ⮚ For Chlamydia —culture on McCoy and HeLa cell lines ⮚ For Trichomonas —detection of trophozoite ⮚ For Candida —detection of budding yeast cells in discharge ⮚ For PCR—can be done for HSV or Chlamydia Treatment Ceftriaxone ⮚ For Chlamydia —Doxycycline ⮚ For Trichomonas —Metronidazole ⮚ For Candida —Clotrimazole (as vaginal cream or tablet)

questions.text: A patient with PUO was suspected of having Brucellosis. Serum sample was sent for the standard agglutination test (SAT). The test came negative initially but turned out to be positive after dilution of the serum sample. The phenomenon can be explained by:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prozone phenomenon A false negative response can be observed due to prozone phenomenon due to high antibody titers which interferes with lattice formation for visualization of a positive test. The problem can be overcome by testing in appropriate dilutions. Prozone phenomenon may occur secondary to hyper antigenemia, possibly leading to false-negative results. Accordingly, routine dilution of sera (typically beyond 1:320) is necessary to avoid this problem. At high antibody concentrations, the number of antibody binding sites may greatly exceed the number of epitopes present in the antigens. As a result, most antibodies bind antigen only univalently instead of multivalent. Antibodies that bind univalently cannot cross-link one antigen to another. Excess of an antibody also inhibits agglutination reaction; this inhibition is called prozone phenomenon.

questions.text: A patient with urticaria who was on steroid treatment presented with nocturnal cough. BAL specimen revealed the presence of certain larvae. The probable causative organism is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Strongyloides stercoralis Given case scenario points to the diagnosis of Strongyloidiasis. Filariform larvae can sometimes be seen in respiratory samples in patients with immunosuppression (i.e. induced by steroids) apart from GI symptoms.

Highyeild:

Up to 75% of people with chronic strongyloidiasis have mild peripheral eosinophilia or elevated IgE levels. Hyperinfection syndrome and disseminated strongyloidiasis are most frequently associated with subclinical infection in patients receiving high-dose corticosteroids. Subsequent impaired host immunity leads to accelerated autoinfection and an overwhelming number of migrating larvae. In chronic strongyloidiasis and in hyperinfection syndrome, the larvae are limited to the GI tract and the lungs, whereas in disseminated strongyloidiasis the larvae invade numerous organs. The subcutaneous migration of filariform larvae in the auto infective cycle, or “larva currens”, presents as a recurrent serpiginous maculopapular or urticarial rash along the buttocks, perineum, and thighs due to repeated autoinfection. This rash usually advances very rapidly (up to 10 cm/hr).

questions.text: A child presented with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. The enrichment medium for the most likely causative organism is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Selenite F broth Selenite F broth is used for isolation of dysentery causing pathogens such as Shigella and gastroenteritis causing like Salmonella.

Extraedge:

To optimize detection of Shigella in stool, samples should be plated on MacConkey and either xylose-lysine-deoxycholate, Hektoen enteric, or deoxycholate citrate agar. Colonies are bluish-green on Hektoen agar and do not have the black center seen with Salmonella , as Shigella do not produce H2S. Shigella do not ferment lactose and xylose and are relatively inert biochemically. Some strains of sonnei are exceptions and may ferment lactose. Most isolates do not produce gas, except some S. flexneri . Lysine decarboxylase tests are typically negative for Shigella . Groups A, B, and C have similar biochemical characteristics, but sonnei has ornithine decarboxylase activity and beta-galactosidase activity. Active or typical coli strains can be distinguished from Shigella by several tests, including lysine decarboxylase, motility, gas production, acetate utilization, and mucate and lactose fermentation. Common Characteristics of Bacterial Diarrheal Pathogens Salmonella Salmonella typhi Shigella Campylobacter Source Incubation Carriage Pathogenesis Duration Bacteremia Complications Fecal/oral Milk/egg/meat Turtles 6 to 72 hrs Yes Enterotoxin 2 to 7 days 5% to 40% (infants) Meningitis Skeletal Myocarditis Pneumonia Fecal/oral Water 7 to 14 days Yes Endotoxin 2 to 3 weeks Common Rash Gastrointestinal bleeding Skeletal Hepatitis Cholecystitis Fecal/oral Food/water 12 to 48 hrs No Invasive cytotoxin 2 to 5 days Uncommon Seizures (? toxin) Hemolytic uremic syndrome Perforation Fecal/oral Water/dairy, meat (esp. poultry) Animal contact 2 to 4 days No Invasive (esp. ileum) 2 to 7 days Uncommon (<1%) Campylobacter fetus Meningitis Cholecystitis Urinary tract infection Spontaneous abortion

questions.text: A child presented with fever, cough, conjunctivitis and bluish white spots in his buccal mucosa. This is followed by development of a rash all over his body. The correct description for the causative pathogen is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Enveloped ssRNA Koplik spots are associated with measles, a common childhood infection caused by measles virus which is a ss-enveloped RNA virus. Common symptoms include fever, skin rash, cough, coryza and conjunctivitis. It can be serious but is easily preventable by vaccine, MMR vaccine. Koplik spots start as bluish-white “grains of salt on a red background” opposite the molars on the buccal mucosa. They may also appear on conjunctival folds or on vaginal or gastrointestinal mucosa. Measles morbillivirus (MeV), also called measles virus (MV), is a single-stranded, negative-sense, enveloped, non-segmented RNA virus of the genus Morbillivirus within the family Paramyxoviridae.

questions.text: A patient presented to burn ICU with 70% burns. A sample was collected from the burn site and the test for causative organism revealed it to be an obligate aerobe. The likely causative organism is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a very important obligate aerobic pathogen associated with infection in burn wounds and other conditions especially nosocomial infections. Rest other organisms belong to Enterobacteriaceae and are facultative anaerobes/aerobes. Burn wound sepsis is currently the main cause of morbidity and mortality after burn trauma. Infections by notorious pathogens such as Pseudomonas aeruginosa , Staphylococcus aureus , and Acinetobacter baumannii impair patient recovery and can even lead to fatality. aeruginosa is the only pathogen able to grow within these human fluids. It produces a diffusible pigment as shown in the picture.

questions.text: A group of friends was partying till late night. Few of them ate pastries kept outside who presented with vomiting in the early morning. What is the causative organism?
questions.correct_answer: A. Entero toxin of S aureus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Entero toxin of S aureus Heat-stable enterotoxins are the most notable virulence factors associated with Staphylococcus aureus , a common pathogen associated with serious community and hospital acquired diseases. Staphylococcal enterotoxins (SEs) cause toxic shock-like syndromes and have been implicated in food poisoning. Symptoms of Staphylococcal food poisoning (SFP) have a rapid onset (2–8 h) , due to preformed toxin and include nausea, violent vomiting, abdominal cramping, with or without diarrhea. The disease is usually self-limiting and typically resolves within 24–48 h after onset. Occasionally it can be severe enough to warrant hospitalization, particularly when infants, elderly or debilitated people are concerned.

Extraedge:

Exotoxin Endotoxin Species Some species of both Gram-positive and Gram-negative bacteria Most Gram-negative bacteria and Listeria Protein Location Proteins secreted from cell Part of cell (lipopolysaccharide) that fragments off Gene Location Genes for exotoxin are in plasmid or bacteriophage Genes for endotoxin are on bacterial chromosome Toxicity High toxicity Low toxicity Antigenicity Highly antigenic (host forms antibodies called antitoxins) Poorly antigenic Vaccine Vaccine available (formed from toxoids) No vaccine available Heat Stability Heat labile Heat stable Example Think cholera, tetanus, botulism Think meningococcemia, sepsis

Table:

#MANTRA Clinical and epidemiological similarities in B. cereus emetic foodborne illness and those caused by staphylococcal intoxication Factors B. cereus Emetic syndrome Staphylococcal intoxication Onset of symptons (h) 1-5 2-6 Duration of illness (h) 6-24 6-14 Diarrhea, abdominal cramps Fairly common Common Nausea, vomiting Predominant Predominant Pathogenesis Principal food vehicles Toxin-mediateda Cook rice and pasta Toxin-mediateda Cold cooked meat and poultry, dairy products a. Toxin preformed in food

questions.text: Microfilaria with sheath and no nuclei in the tip of tail:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Wuchereria Wuchereria bancrofti Sheath, no nuclei in the tip of the tail Brugia malayi Sheath, 2 distinct nuclei in the tip of the tail Loa loa Sheath, nuclei extending to the tip of the tail Onchocerca volvulus (skin) No sheath, no nuclei in the tip of the tail Mansonella perstans No sheath, nuclei extending to the tip of the tail Mansonella ozzardi No sheath, no nuclei in the tip of the tail Mansonella streptocerca (skin) No sheath, nuclei extending to the tip of the hooked tail

questions.text: A pregnant female whose niece recently contacted with the infection of varicella is negative for the antibodies for the same, this would mean?
questions.correct_answer: B. She is susceptible to chickenpox
questions.explanation:
Solution:

She is susceptible to chickenpox Definite history of chickenpox is the usual method to assess the immunity against chickenpox. However, individuals and parents tend to forget about prior history as they grow older and reach adulthood. Thus, definite history alone cannot be a true indicator of immunity for chickenpox. Screening for the presence of IgG antibodies for Varicella virus is a useful method to assess the immunity against the same. Presence of IgG antibodies against Varicella indicates immunity, and conversely, its absence indicates susceptibility. Indirect immunoenzyme assay kit to test IgG antibodies against Varicella virus is available.

questions.text: There is an outbreak of acute encephalitis cases in the Gorakhpur, Uttar Pradesh community. According to the universal immunization schedule, the route of mass vaccination for the likely infection is?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Live and SC The given case scenario refers to an outbreak of Japanese encephalitis (buzzwords: Acute encephalitis cases, endemic in Uttar Pradesh, Vaccination in UP). Japanese Encephalitis is a viral infection caused by RNA viruses belonging to the Flavivirus It is a zoonosis – an animal disease that can spread to humans – primarily transmitted by evening biting Culex mosquitoes that feed on infected birds, pigs and other mammals passing the infection to humans living and working in rural areas around rice paddies and irrigation systems. Live attenuated SA-14-14-2 vaccine against Japanese encephalitis (JE) was introduced in the routine immunization under Universal Immunization Program in the 181 endemic districts of India. Recently, the Government of India has announced the introduction of one dose of JE vaccine for adults in endemic districts. Vaccination is recommended for persons travelling extensively in rural areas, long-term travelers, and persons on work assignments in endemic areas.

questions.text: In Kerala post floods, People complain of fever, doxycycline prophylactically distributed, along which insecticide prefer :
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zinc phosphide The given scenario is consistent with occurrence of Leptospirosis. Post flood/earthquake situation where Doxycycline used as prophylaxis is indicative of a leptospirosis outbreak. Prevention and Control: Personal protection: Hygienic methods such as avoidance of direct and indirect human contact animal urine are recommended as preventive measures. Workers in flooded fields should be cautioned against direct contact with contaminated water or mud and should be advised to use rubber shoes and gloves. In case of any cuts or abrasion on the lower extremities of the body, the worker should apply an antiseptic ointment. Health education: The main preventive measure for leptospirosis is to create awareness about the disease and its prevention. This has to be conceptualized through intensive educational campaigns. Chemoprophylaxis: During the peak transmission season Doxycycline 200 mg, once a week, may be given to agricultural workers, canal cleaning workers from where clustering of cases has been reported. The chemoprophylaxis should be for six weeks and never to be extended for more than eight weeks. Rodent control: Usage of rat poison such as Zn Phosphide for rodent control

questions.text: A truck driver presented with complaints of painless indurated genital ulcer after unprotected intercourse. Motility of the causative organism can be detected by the following microscope:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dark field Dark field microscopy is used for viewing motile thin slender organisms like Spirochetes. Microscopy to visualize the organisms can be done by Dark ground microscopy Direct IF staining for pallidum (DFA-TP) Silver impregnation method Levaditi stain (for tissue section) Fontana stain (smear)
